subject: a question regarding Unicode script submission
msgSnippet: Messrs. Everson and Cowan, I apologize for the imposition, but the web resources you have provided have proven very useful for me in beginning the process of
messageBody:
Messrs. Everson and Cowan,

I apologize for the imposition, but the web resources you have provided
have proven very useful for me in beginning the process of registering
a script for inclusion into Unicode. I am hoping you can easily answer
a question I have regarding re-use of characters already within the
Unicode range.

I am working on a proposal for Quickscript, or the 'Second Shaw
Alphabet.' This was created by Kingsley Read after some years of
experience with Shavian which you yourself submitted for inclusion in
Unicode. The number of characters in the two alphabets is very
similar: Quickscript omits one character from Shavian, and adds four
more. Visually, however, the alphabets are quite distinct. Some
shapes have been reused, but for different phonemes; and other
characters had their shapes changed to facilitate handwritten text.

Do you think that this script should be encoded as a separate range
from Shavian, or rather that the four additional characters should be
added to the range. If the two scripts occupy the same range, would
that mean that documents encoded as UTF-8 would only be able to show
one or the other, not both concurrently?

There is a somewhat active user group for Quickscript at
http://groups.yahoo.com/Read_Alphabet/

Thank you for any information you can provide!

oliver langan

Messrs. Everson and Cowan,

I apologize for the imposition, but the web resources you have provided 
have proven very useful for me in beginning the process of registering 
a script for inclusion into Unicode.  I am hoping you can easily answer 
a question I have regarding re-use of characters already within the 
Unicode range.

I am working on a proposal for Quickscript, or the 'Second Shaw 
Alphabet.'  This was created by Kingsley Read after some years of 
experience with Shavian which you yourself submitted for inclusion in 
Unicode.  The number of characters in the two alphabets is very 
similar: Quickscript omits one character from Shavian, and adds four 
more.  Visually, however, the alphabets are quite distinct.  Some 
shapes have been reused, but for different phonemes; and other 
characters had their shapes changed to facilitate handwritten text.

Do you think that this script should be encoded as a separate range 
from Shavian, or rather that the four additional characters should be 
added to the range.  If the two scripts occupy the same range, would 
that mean that documents encoded as UTF-8 would only be able to show 
one or the other, not both concurrently?

There is a somewhat active user group for Quickscript at 
http://groups.yahoo.com/Read_Alphabet/

Thank you for any information you can provide!

oliver langan
